Los Animas Hospital as of 1900

2. Lampson (413,416) states that Finlay wantedvisited Reed June 26, 1900, the very day after Reed
arrived in Havana (June 25). Kean says very doubtful

3. Epidemic broke out among United States' troops at Pinar del Rio in July 1900.
thought by local authorities to be malaria. Agramonte says he went alone
to Pinar del Rio July 19, recognized yellow fever and sent for Reed. Reed
(Senate Doc. 61-p. 165; J. Hygiene II: April 1902) says “last week of July.”
Kelly (p.124) says Reed and Agramonte went to Pinar del Rio together July 31
Which version correct? Did Agramonte go alone first and send for Reed (as
seems likely), or is Kelly's version correct. It seems likely that Agramonte
went alone July 19, sent for Reed who was with Agramonte in Pinar “the last
week in July.”

4. “First week in August”--commissions called on Finlay for reprints and mosquito
larvae. What was the exact date?

5. When was Reed recalled to Washington? Senate document (page 90, 94) says August 2.
Lampson (page 436) says August 4.

6. When did Reed leave Havana for Washington? Kelly said August 4; Lampson said
August 5.

7. Who were the various Americans (besides Lazear, Carroll, Pinto and Agramonte (?)
who were first bitten by Lazear's mosquitos. (Table III--Senate Doc. p.62)
see Ki answer

8. Carroll was bitten August 27, 1900 and developed yellow fever August 31. Moran
says Carroll's case was not regarded as one of experimental yellow fever.
Record doctored?

9. Is Agramonte's story regarding the case of Dean correct? Agramonte gives the
story that Dean walked by and granted Lazear's request that he (Dean) be bitten
Kissinger says Lazear put mosquitos on Dean while Dean was asleep.

10. When Carroll got yellow fever he was taken to the “yellow fever ward” (Argramonte)
to the “yellow fever camp” (Carroll--NY M J)

11. According to Lampson (455) Reed cabled (Sept 6) orders to suspend further inoculations
until his return from Washington to Havana. Is this true? I find this comment
nowhere else.

12. What is true version of Lazear's inoculation? The official version says he was bitten
in Los Animas by a stray mosquito, September 13, but Agramonte (see his letter)
infers in one place and states in another place (unpublished) that Lazear had himself
bitten deliberately and when he actually got sick and realized that he had dis-
obeyed Reed's orders, etc. he kept it a secret at first. Miss Agramonte says the
Los Animas Hospital story was connected for purposes connected with pension.

13. What was actual date of Reed's return to Cuba? Agramonte says it was “early in
October” 1900.
Kean say oll 4 on transport work

item.p:
14. Did Reed, Carroll and Agramonte all visit Wood (October 12?) to get his help for the
commission's work?

list.item:
15. Reed returned to Washington about third week in October to get the backing of the
Surgeon General (says Ireland) and to give preliminary report. Carroll took short
vacation to recuperate from his yellow fever. Did he accompany Reed north?
Lampson says so).
16. Do you know exact site of Camp Lazear, circumstances of how it was chosen, etc.

17. Reed, etc. (Senate Doc. p.71) says Dr. Roger Ames was among the personnel of Camp Lazear.
Moran disputes this and says that Ames stayed at Columbia Barracks and was never (?)
at Camp Lazear. Dr. Cooke was the only officer constantly at Camp Lazear but since
he was being experimented upon himself he was really not in charge. There was
no doctor “in charge” except Reed who went out to the camp at least twice a day.
Is this correct?

18. Who were personnel of Camp Lazear. Senate Doc 61 (P. 19-71top-97) says Ames, Cooke and
11 soldiers, but on page 71 (bottom) it gives a list which totals up to 16.

19. Who were the “two non-immunes” who were in the non-infected side of the mosquito bldg.
#2. (Noted on pages 10 and 86 of Senate Doc.) Did these same two non-immunes later
go over into the infected side? Gorgas (Senate Doc p. 243 says, yes. Moran says, no.

item.p:
20. Kelly (page 257) says commission wound up its work February 1901 and that Reed and
Carroll returned to the United States together. Moran says that Carroll did not
return with Reed, that Reed, Moran, and Kissinger left Havana in the same boat
(Morro Castle) February 18 or 19, 1901.
